qas.question: What type of Islam is most common in Nigeria?
What school of Sunni Islam is most common in Nigeria?
What Islamic law is being used in some Nigerian states?
What Nigerian state is trying to make Sharia law part of its constitution?

context: The vast majority of Muslims in Nigeria are <a0_0>Sunni<a0_0/> belonging to <a1_0>Maliki school of jurisprudence<a1_0/>; however, a sizeable minority also belongs to Shafi madhhab. A large number of Sunni Muslims are members of Sufi brotherhoods. Most Sufis follow the Qadiriyya, Tijaniyyah and/or the Mouride movements. A significant Shia minority exists (see Shia in Nigeria). Some northern states have incorporated <a2_0>Sharia<a2_0/> law into their previously secular legal systems, which has brought about some controversy. <a3_0>Kano<a3_0/> State has sought to incorporate Sharia law into its constitution. The majority of Quranists follow the Kalo Kato or Quraniyyun movement. There are also Ahmadiyya and Mahdiyya minorities.
